Award.AwardTitle: Conductivity in Ionic Liquids: Decoupling of ions diffusion from structural relaxation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ionic liquids present a relatively new class of materials important for great variety of applications, from batteries and fuel cells, to "green" solvents and bio-technologies. Unique properties of these liquids (e.g. ionic conduction, extremely low vapor pressure) give them significant potential for use in future sustainable energy applications and environmentally friendly chemistry. Due to large variety of possible constituent ions, this class of materials potentially represents millions of chemically different liquids. This diversity opens tremendous opportunity for fine tuning of the ionic liquids properties for any desired applications. However, rational design of these materials requires fundamental understanding of the relationship between their chemical structure and macroscopic properties. In particular, understanding parameters that control molecular motions, ionic conductivity and viscosity is crucial for many applications of ionic liquids. This award supports Prof. Alexei Sokolov of the University of Tennessee, Knoxville and his research group to study the microscopic mechanisms controlling ionic conductivity and dynamics in ionic liquids. The research plan utilizes a combination of dielectric spectroscopy, light and neutron scattering studies and viscosity measurements. Using their expertise in dynamics of glass forming liquids and polymers, Prof. Sokolov and his research group expect to develop a comprehensive description of the mechanism of ionic conductivity in ionic liquids, its dependence on chemical structure, size of the ions and cation-anion interactions. They also expect the results of their work to deepen understanding of the dynamics of ionic liquids and to reveal the role of Coulombic interactions in structural relaxation of this new class of materials.

Room temperature ionic liquids present new class of materials with significant potential for use in current and future sustainable energy and green chemistry applications. Understanding ionic motions and structural relaxation in these materials is crucial for rational design and synthesis of new materials with properties desired for particular applications. This project focuses on fundamental understanding of the molecular level mechanisms controlling the macroscopic properties of ionic liquids. The results may lead to developments of more efficient electrolytes for batteries, supercapacitors and other electrical energy storage applications. Education of specialists for future technologies is a significant part of the proposed program. Graduate and undergraduate students are actively involved in this research. Outreach activities to recruit future scientists from underrepresented groups and K-12 students are also planned. This project also promotes active collaboration with national multi-user facilities at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ionic Liquids (ILs) present a relatively new class of materials with potential of broad applications from electrical energy storage and conversion to ecologically friendly solvents, and to some biotechnologies. Their unique properties are defined by ionic interactions and dynamics. Our project is focused on fundamental understanding of ion motions in these liquids. This understanding is instrumental in design of new functional materials with desired macroscopic properties.

During the award period we deepen our understanding of how chemical structure and molecular interactions affect ionic conductivity in ILs. Ionic conductivity in these liquids essentially follows viscosity and can be additionally suppressed by ion aggregations. The latter should be avoided if high ionic conductivity is desired.

In contrast, our studies revealed that polymerized ionic liquids show strong decoupling of ion dynamics from structural relaxation. These results clearly indicate a qualitative change in conductivity mechanism by moving from small molecular to polymerized ionic liquids. Strong decoupling of proton conductivity from viscosity has been also found in several protic ionic liquids. This finding suggests that proton transfer mechanism dominates in these liquids and provides very high proton mobility. All these results and knowledge are crucial in design of electrolytes for batteries and fuel cells applications, and for understanding of proton transfer mechanism in some biological systems.

In addition, we discovered that quantum effects might play significant role of dynamics of light molecules, such as water, and in proton conductivity. Quantum effects in molecular motions are usually neglected. However, this traditional view appears to be wrong in the case of light molecules. Quantum effects significantly broaden the glass transition range, lead to an unusual temperature dependence of materials properties and enhancement of proton conductivity. This discovery calls for significant revisions of current models used to describe the dynamics of water and some corrections in analysis of proton conductivity.

Results of our studies have been published in 15 peer-review papers and were presented on many National and International Meetings. These results deepen fundamental understanding of ion dynamics, which is crucial for many energy related technologies and some biotechnologies.

Besides these scientific achievements, the NSF funding helped significantly in development of human resources and education. Three graduate students and one undergraduate student were actively involved in this research. One of them successfully graduated with PhD and is now a postdoc at university of Pennsylvania. Two other graduated with Masters degree. Four postdoctoral researchers were also involved in this project. One of them received a faculty position at the University of Tennessee, and another one received a staff scientist position at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Students and postdocs in our group were also involved in Science Olympiad and Science Fair events for school kids organized at the University of Tennessee. PI of the project, Dr. Sokolov, presented many tutorial lectures on National and International meetings educating young scientists in use of scattering techniques and dielectric spectroscopy for studies of Soft Materials. He also presented a lecture for more than 100 high-school students attending Governor's school at UT during summer 2015.


Last Modified: 10/06/2015
Modified by: Alexei Sokolov
